qti-item-body.p: In 1950, 400,000 lions roamed Africa. Today, fewer than 40,000 are left. Why? There are a few reasons. Humans have taken over most of the lands where lions used to live. Hunters kill lions for their fur. And Maasai farmers hoping to keep their livestock safe also hunt lions.

When scientist Leela Hazzah moved to Kenya, she spoke to many Maasai, who felt frustrated that they were often left out of local conservation programs. Those conversations inspired an idea: What if Maasai warriors were hired to protect lions? Soon after, Hazzah created Lion Guardians. The group uses technology and Maasai tracking techniques to find and protect lions in the area. Today, 40 Lion Guardians protect more than 100 lions from illegal hunting.

qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: Based on the information in the text, what are two reasons why there are so few lions today?
qti-choice-interaction.qti-simple-choice: Hunters illegally kill lions for their teeth and claws.
Farmers hunt lions to protect their animals.
The Lion Guardians use technology and traditional Maasai tracking techniques.
Humans have taken over many areas where lions used to live.
In 1950, about 400,000 lions roamed Africa, but today fewer than 40,000 remain.
